Les pratiques num├йriques des jeunes ne sont pas ce que lтАЩon croitтАжTout d├йbute en 2022 lorsque Luc Truntzler d├йcouvre une ├йtude de Google affirmant que pr├иs de 40% des 18-24 ans utilisent Tiktok plut├┤t que Google Maps pour trouver un restaurant. ┬л Cette statistique mтАЩa surprise┬л , avoue-t-il.Pourtant, ce Toulousain de 39 ans est un expert des usages digitaux et notamment de lтАЩintelligence artificielle conversationnelle.┬л Bien que je travaille dans le num├йrique, jтАЩai alors senti que je pourrai rapidement devenir has been sur certaines pratiques ┬╗Plus de 200 coll├йgiens et lyc├йens dтАЩOccitanie interrog├йs┬л Ma plus grande motivation ├йtait de d├йcouvrir de nouveaux usages du num├йrique ├а lтАЩimage du concept du mentorat invers├й o├╣ la jeune g├йn├йration enseigne ├а ses a├оn├йs de nouvelles pratiques. JтАЩesp├йrai ainsi ├кtre cal├й et pr├кt pour les usages ├а venir ┬╗Avec lтАЩaide du Rectorat de Toulouse et de Montpellier, notre expert lance une vaste enqu├кte aupr├иs de 215 coll├йgiens, lyc├йens et enseignants.┬л A ma grande d├йception, je nтАЩai pas pu d├йcouvrir de nouvelles pratiques ┬╗Apr├иs plusieurs semaines dтАЩaudit, Luc Truntzler nтАЩen revient pas. Les conclusions d├йconstruisent de nombreux clich├йs sur la jeunesse et leur utilisation du num├йrique.Constat n┬░1 : la maturit├й des jeunes sur les r├йseaux sociauxSi les 15-20 ans utilisent essentiellement 5 applications : Tiktok, Instagram, Snapchat, Youtube et Netflix, ils sont ┬л mieux arm├йs et ├йduqu├йs sur les sujets de vie priv├йe┬л .┬л Contrairement ├а certaines id├йes pr├йcon├зues, cette g├йn├йration sтАЩexpose peu et publie peu en public et si elle publie, elle ne passe pas des heures ├а retoucher une image qui sтАЩalignerait avec certaines normes discutables de la soci├йt├й ┬╗Constat n┬░2 : privil├йgier un t├йl├йphone des ann├йes 2000 au lieu dтАЩavoir le dernier Iphone┬л JтАЩai aussi ├йt├й agr├йablement surpris par la forte sensibilisation de la nouvelle g├йn├йration aux sujets ├йcologiques. ┬╗┬л Il nтАЩy a pas de courses ├а avoir le dernier Iphone ou Samsung. Du moment que le t├йl├йphone fonctionne, la majorit├й des jeunes est satisfaite. Le fameux Nokia 3310 revient m├кme ├а la mode ┬╗Constat n┬░3 : Scroller sur TikTok mais pas nтАЩimporte commentLтАЩ├йtude r├йv├иle que de nombreux jeunes classent dans des dossiers de lтАЩapplication les vid├йos quтАЩils d├йcouvrent pour les r├йutiliser par la suite (recette de cuisine, astuce de bricolage, entra├оnement sportif,,тАж).Par ailleurs, la g├йn├йration Z pr├йf├иre suivre des cr├йateurs de contenu sur lтАЩactualit├й (comme Hugo Decrypte) ou des enseignants qui font le buzz sur les r├йseaux.┬л La meilleure solution restera bien entendu de lever les yeux de ses applications mais si on doit y replonger, autant avoir un usage intelligent ! ┬╗┬л Se fixer par exemple un objectif comme identifier 1 vid├йo ├а classer dans ses dossiers lors dтАЩune s├йance de scrolling de vid├йo peut aider ├а limiter cette session de scrolling et g├йn├йrer un autre b├йn├йfice : celui dтАЩavoir pu structurer une nouvelle connaissance┬л Constat n┬░4 : regarder une s├йrie Netflix entre 2 coursDans les ├йchanges avec les enseignants, lтАЩexpert est frapp├й par cette utilisation inattendue.┬л Beaucoup de jeunes profitent des pauses entre deux cours pour se plonger dans une s├йrie Netflix, ├а la sonnerie, il change alors de Game of Thrones ├а un cours dтАЩhistoire/g├йo. ┬╗┬л Ces applications mobiles (Netflix ou TikTok) ont un pouvoir de captation dтАЩattention et de g├йn├йration de dopamine tr├иs important, challengeant encore plus lтАЩenseignant dans sa mission de capturer cette pr├йcieuse attention des ├йl├иves pour leurs cours ┬╗Constat n┬░5 : les ├йtudiants sont pr├кts ├а acheter @Pepijn It will be well-deserved, for this neat idea. I have yet to hear anyone in 'real life' talk about the fact that using ChatGPT or other generative AI tools has an environmental cost at all, let alone a high one. I have literally only seen it mentioned online, so anecdotally, I think there's a big need for basic awareness-raising to start with. Everyone is using AI for everything, like it's a magic wand, is my experience so far.

I did note the absurdity recently though of my countering a clearly AI-written bit of baloney with a wordy mythbusting document, only to then have a meeting discussing it in which the chair used ChatGPT to summarise my reasoning.

My org is having a resurgence of long-form writing in the way it operates lately, which I'm very encouraging of.  It's not appropriate in most orgs, but my place desperately needs a keener focus on information accuracy and rigour, and so far it's going well.One thing I've noted is that in these weird early days of AI folks really engage well with well-written work.  Even folks less dorky about writing than me can identify the ChatGPT 'tone' and welcome a more human tone in good writing.

Yes, that'd be my approach, too. They need to be forced put in digital watermarks so everyone can check if an article is from ChatGPT, or if an image is fake. We could easily do this with regulation and hefty fines. More or less robust watermarks are available and anything would be better than nothing. OpenAI even developed a text watermarking solution. They just don't activate it. (https://www.theverge.com/2024/8/4/24213268/openai-chatgpt-text-watermark-cheat-detection-tool)
Another pet peeve of mine are these "nude" apps that swap faces or generate nude pictures from someones photos. There are services out there that happily generate nudes from children's pictures. I've filed a report with some European CSAM program, after that outcry in Spain where some school kid generated unethical images of their classmates. (Just in case the police doesn't read the news...) And half a year later, that app was still online. I suppose it still is... I really don't know why we allow things like that.

Automated, Unsupervised, and Auto-parameterized Inference of Data Patterns and Anomaly DetectionQiaolin Qin, Heng Li, Ettore Merlo, Maxime Lamothehttps://arxiv.org/abs/2412.05240 https://arxiv.org/pdf/2412.05240 https://arxiv.org/html/2412.05240arXiv:2412.05240v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: With the advent of data-centric and machine learning (ML) systems, data quality is playing an increasingly critical role in ensuring the overall quality of software systems. Data preparation, an essential step towards high data quality, is known to be a highly effort-intensive process. Although prior studies have dealt with one of the most impacting issues, data pattern violations, these studies usually require data-specific configurations (i.e., parameterized) or use carefully curated data as learning examples (i.e., supervised), relying on domain knowledge and deep understanding of the data, or demanding significant manual effort. In this paper, we introduce RIOLU: Regex Inferencer auto-parameterized Learning with Uncleaned data. RIOLU is fully automated, automatically parameterized, and does not need labeled samples. RIOLU can generate precise patterns from datasets in various domains, with a high F1 score of 97.2%, exceeding the state-of-the-art baseline. In addition, according to our experiment on five datasets with anomalies, RIOLU can automatically estimate a data column's error rate, draw normal patterns, and predict anomalies from unlabeled data with higher performance (up to 800.4% improvement in terms of F1) than the state-of-the-art baseline, even outperforming ChatGPT in terms of both accuracy (12.3% higher F1) and efficiency (10% less inference time). A variant of RIOLU, with user guidance, can further boost its precision, with up to 37.4% improvement in terms of F1. Our evaluation in an industrial setting further demonstrates the practical benefits of RIOLU.
